WGI

Solar_activity_S.html

Solar activity Â« WGI Â»

AR6

General term collectively describing a variety of magnetic phenomena on the Sun such as sunspots, faculae (bright areas), and flares (emission of high-energy particles). It varies on time scales from minutes to millions of years. The solar cycle, with an average duration of 11 years, is an example of a quasi-regular change in solar activity.

Solar_activity.html

Solar activity

General term collectively describing a variety of magnetic phenomena on the Sun such as sunspots, faculae (bright areas), and flares (emission of high-energy particles). It varies on time scales from minutes to millions of years. The solar cycle, with an average duration of 11 years, is an example of a quasi-regular change in solar activity.

WGI

Solar_cycle__11_year__S.html

Solar cycle (11-year) Â« WGI Â»

AR6

A quasi-regular modulation of solar activity with varying amplitude and a period of between 8 and 14 years.

Solar_cycle__11_year_.html

Solar cycle (11-year)

A quasi-regular modulation of solar activity with varying amplitude and a period of between 8 and 14 years.

WGI

Solar_energy_S.html

Solar energy Â« WGIII Â»

AR6

Energy from the Sun. Often the phrase is used to mean energy that is captured from solar radiation either as heat, as light that is converted into chemical energy by natural or artificial photosynthesis, or by photovoltaic panels and converted directly into electricity.

Solar_energy.html

Solar energy

Energy from the Sun. Often the phrase is used to mean energy that is captured from solar radiation either as heat, as light that is converted into chemical energy by natural or artificial photosynthesis, or by photovoltaic panels and converted directly into electricity.

WGIII

Solar_radiation_S.html

Solar radiation Â« WGI Â»

AR6

Electromagnetic radiation emitted by the Sun with a spectrum close to that of a black body with a temperature of 5770 K. The radiation peaks in visible wavelengths. When compared to the terrestrial radiation it is often referred to as shortwave radiation.

Solar_radiation.html

Solar radiation

Electromagnetic radiation emitted by the Sun with a spectrum close to that of a black body with a temperature of 5770 K. The radiation peaks in visible wavelengths. When compared to the terrestrial radiation it is often referred to as shortwave radiation.

WGI

Solar_radiation_modification__SRM__S.html

Solar radiation modification (SRM) Â« WGI,WGIII,WGII Â»

AR6

Refers to a range of radiation modification measures not related to greenhouse gas (GHG) mitigation that seek to limit global warming. Most methods involve reducing the amount of incoming solar radiation reaching the surface, but others also act on the longwave radiation budget by reducing optical thickness and cloud lifetime.

Sub-terms
  • Cirrus cloud thinning (CCT)
  • Marine cloud brightening (MCB)
  • Stratospheric aerosol injection (SAI)

Solar_radiation_modification__SRM_.html

Solar radiation modification

Refers to a range of radiation modification measures not related to greenhouse gas (GHG) mitigation that seek to limit global warming. Most methods involve reducing the amount of incoming solar radiation reaching the surface, but others also act on the longwave radiation budget by reducing optical thickness and cloud lifetime.

Sub-terms
  • Cirrus cloud thinning (CCT)
  • Marine cloud brightening (MCB)
  • Stratospheric aerosol injection (SAI)
WGI,WGIII,WGII
SRM

Solubility_pump_S.html

Solubility pump Â« WGI Â»

AR6

A physicochemical process that transports dissolved inorganic carbon from the oceanâs surface to its interior. The solubility pump is primarily driven by the solubility of carbon dioxide (CO2) (with more CO2 dissolving in colder water) and the large-scale, thermohaline patterns of ocean circulation.

Solubility_pump.html

Solubility pump

A physicochemical process that transports dissolved inorganic carbon from the oceanâs surface to its interior. The solubility pump is primarily driven by the solubility of carbon dioxide (CO2) (with more CO2 dissolving in colder water) and the large-scale, thermohaline patterns of ocean circulation.

WGI

Solution_space_S.html

Solution space Â« WGII Â»

AR6

The set of biophysical, cultural, socio-economic and political-institutional dimensions within which opportunities and constraints determine why, how, when and who acts to reduce climate risks. Within these dimensions, there are âhardâ (unsurpassable) limits and âsoftâ(surpassable) limits. The boundaries of the solution space are path dependent, contested and in constant flux (Haasnoot et. al. 2020).

Solution_space.html

Solution space

The set of biophysical, cultural, socio-economic and political-institutional dimensions within which opportunities and constraints determine why, how, when and who acts to reduce climate risks. Within these dimensions, there are âhardâ (unsurpassable) limits and âsoftâ(surpassable) limits. The boundaries of the solution space are path dependent, contested and in constant flux (Haasnoot et. al. 2020).

WGII

Source_S.html

Source Â« WGIII,WGII,WGI,SYR Â»

AR6

Any process or activity which releases a greenhouse gas (GHG), an aerosol or a precursor of a GHG into the atmosphere (United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) Article 1.9 (UNFCCC, 1992)).

Source.html

Source

Any process or activity which releases a greenhouse gas (GHG), an aerosol or a precursor of a GHG into the atmosphere (United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) Article 1.9 (UNFCCC, 1992)).

WGIII,WGII,WGI,SYR

South_American_monsoon__SAmerM__S.html

South American monsoon (SAmerM) Â« WGI Â»

AR6

The South American monsoon (SAmerM) is a regional circulation characterized by inflow of low-level winds from the Atlantic to South America, including Brazil, Peru, Bolivia and northern Argentina, associated with the development of surface pressure gradients (and intense precipitation) during austral summer (DecemberâJanuaryâFebruary). During SeptemberâOctoberâNovember, areas of intense convection migrate from northwestern South America to the south. Associated with this regime, an upper-tropospheric anticyclone (a.k.a. the Bolivian High) forms over the Altiplano region during the monsoon onset. The SAmerM then retreats during MarchâAprilâMay with a northeastward migration of the convection. Further details on how SAmerM is defined and used throughout the Report are provided in Annex V.

Parent-term
  • Global monsoon

South_American_monsoon__SAmerM_.html

South American monsoon (SAmerM)

The South American monsoon (SAmerM) is a regional circulation characterized by inflow of low-level winds from the Atlantic to South America, including Brazil, Peru, Bolivia and northern Argentina, associated with the development of surface pressure gradients (and intense precipitation) during austral summer (DecemberâJanuaryâFebruary). During SeptemberâOctoberâNovember, areas of intense convection migrate from northwestern South America to the south. Associated with this regime, an upper-tropospheric anticyclone (a.k.a. the Bolivian High) forms over the Altiplano region during the monsoon onset. The SAmerM then retreats during MarchâAprilâMay with a northeastward migration of the convection. Further details on how SAmerM is defined and used throughout the Report are provided in Annex V.

Parent-term
  • Global monsoon
WGI

South_Pacific_Convergence_Zone__SPCZ__S.html

South Pacific Convergence Zone (SPCZ) Â« WGI Â»

AR6

A band of low-level convergence, cloudiness and precipitation ranging from the west Pacific warm pool south-eastwards towards French Polynesia. It is one of the most significant features of subtropical Southern Hemisphere climate. It shares some characteristics with the Inter-tropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ), but is more extratropical in nature, especially east of the International Date Line.

South_Pacific_Convergence_Zone__SPCZ_.html

South Pacific Convergence Zone

A band of low-level convergence, cloudiness and precipitation ranging from the west Pacific warm pool south-eastwards towards French Polynesia. It is one of the most significant features of subtropical Southern Hemisphere climate. It shares some characteristics with the Inter-tropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ), but is more extratropical in nature, especially east of the International Date Line.

WGI
SPCZ

South_and_South_East_Asian_monsoon__SAsiaM__S.html

South and South East Asian monsoon (SAsiaM) Â« WGI Â»

AR6

The South and South East Asian monsoon (SAsiaM) is characterized by pronounced seasonal reversals of wind and precipitation. The SAsiaM region extends across vast geographical areas and several countries, including India, Bangladesh, Nepal, Myanmar, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Thailand, Laos, Cambodia, Vietnam and the Philippines. The SAsiaM starts in late May/early June and progresses towards the north-east, ending in late September/early October. During the core monsoon season, maxima of SAsiaM precipitation are located over the west coast, north-east and central north India, Myanmar and Bangladesh, whereas minima are located over north-west and south-eastern India, western Pakistan, and southeastern and northern Sri Lanka. Further details on how SAsiaM is defined and used throughout the Report are provided in Annex V.

Parent-term
  • Global monsoon

South_and_South_East_Asian_monsoon__SAsiaM_.html

South and South East Asian monsoon (SAsiaM)

The South and South East Asian monsoon (SAsiaM) is characterized by pronounced seasonal reversals of wind and precipitation. The SAsiaM region extends across vast geographical areas and several countries, including India, Bangladesh, Nepal, Myanmar, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Thailand, Laos, Cambodia, Vietnam and the Philippines. The SAsiaM starts in late May/early June and progresses towards the north-east, ending in late September/early October. During the core monsoon season, maxima of SAsiaM precipitation are located over the west coast, north-east and central north India, Myanmar and Bangladesh, whereas minima are located over north-west and south-eastern India, western Pakistan, and southeastern and northern Sri Lanka. Further details on how SAsiaM is defined and used throughout the Report are provided in Annex V.

Parent-term
  • Global monsoon
WGI

Southern_Annular_Mode__SAM__S.html

Southern Annular Mode (SAM) Â« WGI,WGII,WGIII Â»

AR6

The leading mode of climate variability of Southern Hemisphere sea-level pressure and geopotential height, which is associated with the strength and latitudinal shifts in the mid- to high-latitudes westerly wind belt. The SAM is also known as the Antarctic Oscillation (AAO). A positive SAM phase is defined as lower-than-normal pressures over the polar regions and higher-than-normal pressures in the southern mid-latitudes, with a contraction towards Antarctica and strengthening of the westerly wind belt. The negative SAM phase exhibits positive high latitude pressure anomalies, negative mid-latitude pressure anomalies and a weaker westerly flow expanded towards the equator. See Section AIV.2.2 in Annex IV of the AR6 WGI report.

Parent-term
  • Annular modes

Southern_Annular_Mode__SAM_.html

Southern Annular Mode

The leading mode of climate variability of Southern Hemisphere sea-level pressure and geopotential height, which is associated with the strength and latitudinal shifts in the mid- to high-latitudes westerly wind belt. The SAM is also known as the Antarctic Oscillation (AAO). A positive SAM phase is defined as lower-than-normal pressures over the polar regions and higher-than-normal pressures in the southern mid-latitudes, with a contraction towards Antarctica and strengthening of the westerly wind belt. The negative SAM phase exhibits positive high latitude pressure anomalies, negative mid-latitude pressure anomalies and a weaker westerly flow expanded towards the equator. See Section AIV.2.2 in Annex IV of the AR6 WGI report.

Parent-term
  • Annular modes
WGI,WGII,WGIII
SAM

Southern_Ocean_S.html

Southern Ocean Â« WGII Â»

AR6

The ocean region encircling Antarctica that connects the Atlantic, Indian and Pacific Oceans together, allowing inter-ocean exchange. This region is the main source of much of the deep water of the worldâs ocean and also provides the primary return pathway for this deep water to the surface (Marshall and Speer, 2012; Toggweiler and Samuels, 1995). The drawing up of deep waters and the subsequent transport into the ocean interior has major consequences for the global heat, nutrient and carbon balances, as well as the Antarctic cryosphere and marine ecosystems.

Southern_Ocean.html

Southern Ocean

The ocean region encircling Antarctica that connects the Atlantic, Indian and Pacific Oceans together, allowing inter-ocean exchange. This region is the main source of much of the deep water of the worldâs ocean and also provides the primary return pathway for this deep water to the surface (Marshall and Speer, 2012; Toggweiler and Samuels, 1995). The drawing up of deep waters and the subsequent transport into the ocean interior has major consequences for the global heat, nutrient and carbon balances, as well as the Antarctic cryosphere and marine ecosystems.

WGII

Spatial_and_temporal_scales_S.html

Spatial and temporal scales Â« WGII Â»

AR6

Climate may vary on a large range of spatial and temporal scales. Spatial scales may range from local (less than 100 000 km2), through regional (100 000 to 10 million km2) to continental (10 to 100 million km2). Temporal scales may range from seasonal to geological (up to hundreds of millions of years).

Spatial_and_temporal_scales.html

Spatial and temporal scales

Climate may vary on a large range of spatial and temporal scales. Spatial scales may range from local (less than 100 000 km2), through regional (100 000 to 10 million km2) to continental (10 to 100 million km2). Temporal scales may range from seasonal to geological (up to hundreds of millions of years).

WGII

Specific_humidity_S.html

Specific humidity Â« WGI Â»

AR6

The specific humidity specifies the ratio of the mass of water vapour to the total mass of moist air.

Specific_humidity.html

Specific humidity

The specific humidity specifies the ratio of the mass of water vapour to the total mass of moist air.

Spill_over_effect_S.html

Spill-over effect Â« WGIII Â»

AR6

The effects of domestic or sector mitigation measures on other countries or sectors. Spill-over effects can be positive or negative and include effects on trade, (carbon) leakage, transfer of innovations, and diffusion of environmentally sound technology and other issues.

Spill_over_effect.html

Spill-over effect

The effects of domestic or sector mitigation measures on other countries or sectors. Spill-over effects can be positive or negative and include effects on trade, (carbon) leakage, transfer of innovations, and diffusion of environmentally sound technology and other issues.

WGIII

Stadial_or_stade_S.html

Stadial or stade Â« WGI Â»

AR6

A brief period of regional climatic cooling during a glacial or interglacial interval, often characterized by transient glacial advances. Stadials are generally of short duration (hundreds to a few thousand years) compared to glacial or interglacial intervals (lasting many thousands to tens of thousands of years). One example of a regional stadial event is based on millennial scale cooling recorded by oxygen isotope ratios in Greenland ice cores, the so called âGreenland Stadialsâ (Johnsen et al., 1992).

References
- Johnsen, S. J. et al. Irregular glacial interstadials recorded in a new Greenland ice core. Nature 359, 311â313 (1992).

Stadial_or_stade.html

Stadial or stade

A brief period of regional climatic cooling during a glacial or interglacial interval, often characterized by transient glacial advances. Stadials are generally of short duration (hundreds to a few thousand years) compared to glacial or interglacial intervals (lasting many thousands to tens of thousands of years). One example of a regional stadial event is based on millennial scale cooling recorded by oxygen isotope ratios in Greenland ice cores, the so called âGreenland Stadialsâ (Johnsen et al., 1992).

References
- Johnsen, S. J. et al. Irregular glacial interstadials recorded in a new Greenland ice core. Nature 359, 311â313 (1992).
WGI

Standard_S.html

Standard Â« WGII Â»

AR6

Set of rules or codes mandating or defining product performance (e.g., grades, dimensions, characteristics, test methods, and rules for use). Product, technology or performance standards establish minimum requirements for affected products or technologies. Standards impose reductions in greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions associated with the manufacture or use of the products and/or application of the technology.

Standard.html

Standard

Set of rules or codes mandating or defining product performance (e.g., grades, dimensions, characteristics, test methods, and rules for use). Product, technology or performance standards establish minimum requirements for affected products or technologies. Standards impose reductions in greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions associated with the manufacture or use of the products and/or application of the technology.

WGII

Steric_sea_level_change_S.html

Steric sea level change Â« WGI Â»

AR6

Steric sea level change is caused by changes in ocean density and is composed of thermosteric sea level change and halosteric sea level change.

Parent-term
  • Sea level change (sea level rise/sea level fall)

Steric_sea_level_change.html

Steric sea level change

Steric sea level change is caused by changes in ocean density and is composed of thermosteric sea level change and halosteric sea level change.

Parent-term
  • Sea level change (sea level rise/sea level fall)
WGI

Storm_surge_S.html

Storm surge Â« WGI,WGII Â»

AR6

The temporary increase, at a particular locality, in the height of the sea due to extreme meteorological conditions (low atmospheric pressure and/or strong winds). The storm surge is defined as being the excess above the level expected from the tidal variation alone at that time and place.

Storm_surge.html

Storm surge

The temporary increase, at a particular locality, in the height of the sea due to extreme meteorological conditions (low atmospheric pressure and/or strong winds). The storm surge is defined as being the excess above the level expected from the tidal variation alone at that time and place.

WGI,WGII

Storm_tracks_S.html

Storm tracks Â« WGI Â»

AR6

Originally, a term referring to the tracks of individual cyclonic weather systems, but now often generalized to refer to the main regions where the tracks of extratropical disturbances occur as sequences of low (cyclonic) and high (anticyclonic) pressure systems.

Storm_tracks.html

Storm tracks

Originally, a term referring to the tracks of individual cyclonic weather systems, but now often generalized to refer to the main regions where the tracks of extratropical disturbances occur as sequences of low (cyclonic) and high (anticyclonic) pressure systems.

WGI

Storyline_S.html

Storyline Â« WGI,WGII,WGIII Â»

AR6

A way of making sense of a situation or a series of events through the construction of a set of explanatory elements. Usually, it is built on logical or causal reasoning. In climate research, the term storyline is used both in connection to scenarios as related to a future trajectory of the climate and human systems and to a weather or climate event. In this context, storylines can be used to describe plural, conditional possible futures or explanations of a current situation, in contrast to single, definitive futures or explanations.

Sub-terms
  • Physical climate storyline
  • Scenario storyline

Storyline.html

Storyline

A way of making sense of a situation or a series of events through the construction of a set of explanatory elements. Usually, it is built on logical or causal reasoning. In climate research, the term storyline is used both in connection to scenarios as related to a future trajectory of the climate and human systems and to a weather or climate event. In this context, storylines can be used to describe plural, conditional possible futures or explanations of a current situation, in contrast to single, definitive futures or explanations.

Sub-terms
  • Physical climate storyline
  • Scenario storyline
WGI,WGII,WGIII

Stranded_assets_S.html

Stranded assets Â« WGIII,WGII Â»

AR6

Assets exposed to devaluations or conversion to âliabilitiesâ because of unanticipated changes in their initially expected revenues due to innovations and/or evolutions of the business context, including changes in public regulations at the domestic and international levels.

Stranded_assets.html

Stranded assets

Assets exposed to devaluations or conversion to âliabilitiesâ because of unanticipated changes in their initially expected revenues due to innovations and/or evolutions of the business context, including changes in public regulations at the domestic and international levels.

WGIII,WGII

Stratification_S.html

Stratification Â« WGII,WGI Â»

AR6

Process of forming of layers of (ocean) water with different properties such as salinity, density and temperature that act as barriers for water mixing. The strengthening of near-surface stratification generally results in warmer surface waters, decreased oxygen levels in deeper water and intensification of ocean acidification (OA) in the upper ocean.

Stratification.html

Stratification

Process of forming of layers of (ocean) water with different properties such as salinity, density and temperature that act as barriers for water mixing. The strengthening of near-surface stratification generally results in warmer surface waters, decreased oxygen levels in deeper water and intensification of ocean acidification (OA) in the upper ocean.

WGII,WGI

Stratosphere_S.html

Stratosphere Â« WGI Â»

AR6

The highly stratified region of the atmosphere above the tropopause, extending to about 50 km altitude.

Stratosphere.html

Stratosphere

The highly stratified region of the atmosphere above the tropopause, extending to about 50 km altitude.

WGI

Stratosphere_troposphere_exchange__STE__S.html

Stratosphereâtroposphere exchange (STE) Â« WGI Â»

AR6

Stratosphereâtroposphere exchange (STE) is understood as the flux of air or trace constituents across the tropopause, including both directions: the stratosphere to troposphere transport (STT) and troposphere to stratosphere transport (TST). STE is one of the key factors controlling the budgets of ozone, water vapour and other substances in both the troposphere and the lower stratosphere.

Stratosphere_troposphere_exchange__STE_.html

Stratosphereâtroposphere exchange

Stratosphereâtroposphere exchange (STE) is understood as the flux of air or trace constituents across the tropopause, including both directions: the stratosphere to troposphere transport (STT) and troposphere to stratosphere transport (TST). STE is one of the key factors controlling the budgets of ozone, water vapour and other substances in both the troposphere and the lower stratosphere.

WGI
STE

Stratospheric_aerosol_injection__SAI__S.html

Stratospheric aerosol injection (SAI) Â« WGI Â»

AR6

One of several solar radiation modification (SRM) approaches to increase the planetary albedo. In the approach, it is proposed to inject highly reflective aerosols such as sulphates into the lower stratosphere. This is expected to increase the fraction of solar radiation deflected to space resulting in a planetary cooling.

Parent-term
  • Solar radiation modification (SRM)

Stratospheric_aerosol_injection__SAI_.html

Stratospheric aerosol injection

One of several solar radiation modification (SRM) approaches to increase the planetary albedo. In the approach, it is proposed to inject highly reflective aerosols such as sulphates into the lower stratosphere. This is expected to increase the fraction of solar radiation deflected to space resulting in a planetary cooling.

Parent-term
  • Solar radiation modification (SRM)
WGI
SAI

Stratospheric_ozone_S.html

Stratospheric ozone Â« WGI Â»

AR6

Stratospheric ozone describes the ozone (O3) that resides in the stratosphere, the region of the atmosphere which exists between 10 and 50 kilometres above the surface of the earth. Ninety percent of total-column ozone resides in the stratosphere.

Stratospheric_ozone.html

Stratospheric ozone

Stratospheric ozone describes the ozone (O3) that resides in the stratosphere, the region of the atmosphere which exists between 10 and 50 kilometres above the surface of the earth. Ninety percent of total-column ozone resides in the stratosphere.

WGI

Stratospheric_polar_vortex_S.html

Stratospheric polar vortex Â« WGI Â»

AR6

A large-scale region of cold air poleward of approximately 60 degrees that is contained by a strong westerly jet from the tropopause (8â10 km) to the stratopause (50â60 km) and that forms in each hemisphere during the winter half-year. Planetary waves can temporarily disrupt the vortex, producing easterly winds and rapid warming over polar regions in the stratosphere, and leading to substantial weakening or breakdown of the vortex.

Stratospheric_polar_vortex.html

Stratospheric polar vortex

A large-scale region of cold air poleward of approximately 60 degrees that is contained by a strong westerly jet from the tropopause (8â10 km) to the stratopause (50â60 km) and that forms in each hemisphere during the winter half-year. Planetary waves can temporarily disrupt the vortex, producing easterly winds and rapid warming over polar regions in the stratosphere, and leading to substantial weakening or breakdown of the vortex.

WGI

Stratospheric_sounding_unit__SSU__S.html

Stratospheric sounding unit (SSU) Â« WGI Â»

AR6

A three-channel infrared sounder on operational U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) polar-orbiting satellites. The three channels are used to determine profiles of temperature in the stratosphere (AMS, 2021).

References
- AMS, 2021: Glossary of Meteorology. American Meteorological Society (AMS), Boston, MA, USA. Retrieved from: http://glossary.ametsoc.org.

Stratospheric_sounding_unit__SSU_.html

Stratospheric sounding unit

A three-channel infrared sounder on operational U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) polar-orbiting satellites. The three channels are used to determine profiles of temperature in the stratosphere (AMS, 2021).

References
- AMS, 2021: Glossary of Meteorology. American Meteorological Society (AMS), Boston, MA, USA. Retrieved from: http://glossary.ametsoc.org.

AR6

Water flow within a river channel, for example, expressed in m3 sâ1. A synonym for river discharge.

Streamflow.html

Streamflow

Water flow within a river channel, for example, expressed in m3 sâ1. A synonym for river discharge.

WGI,WGII

Stressors_S.html

Stressors Â« WGII Â»

AR6

Events and trends, often not climate-related, that have an important effect on the system exposed and can increase vulnerability to climate-related risk.

Stressors.html

Stressors

Events and trends, often not climate-related, that have an important effect on the system exposed and can increase vulnerability to climate-related risk.

WGII

Subduction_S.html

Subduction Â« WGI Â»

AR6

Ocean process in which surface waters enter the ocean interior from the surface mixed layer through Ekman pumping and lateral advection. The latter occurs when surface waters are advected to a region where the local surface layer is less dense and therefore must slide below the surface layer, usually with no change in density.

Subduction.html

Subduction

Ocean process in which surface waters enter the ocean interior from the surface mixed layer through Ekman pumping and lateral advection. The latter occurs when surface waters are advected to a region where the local surface layer is less dense and therefore must slide below the surface layer, usually with no change in density.

WGI

Subnational_actors_S.html

Subnational actors Â« WGIII Â»

AR6

State/provincial, regional, metropolitan and local/municipal governments as well as non-party stakeholders, such as civil society, the private sector, cities and other subnational authorities, local communities and indigenous peoples.

Subnational_actors.html

Subnational actors

State/provincial, regional, metropolitan and local/municipal governments as well as non-party stakeholders, such as civil society, the private sector, cities and other subnational authorities, local communities and indigenous peoples.

Sudden_stratospheric_warming__SSW__S.html

Sudden stratospheric warming (SSW) Â« WGI Â»

AR6

A phenomena of rapid warming in the stratosphere at high latitudes (sometimes more than 50Â°C in 1â2 days) that can cause breakdown of stratospheric polar vortices.

Sudden_stratospheric_warming__SSW_.html

Sudden stratospheric warming

A phenomena of rapid warming in the stratosphere at high latitudes (sometimes more than 50Â°C in 1â2 days) that can cause breakdown of stratospheric polar vortices.

A set of measures and daily practices that avoid demand for energy, materials, land and water while delivering human well-being for all within planetary boundaries.

Sulphur_hexafluoride__SF6__S.html

Sulphur hexafluoride (SF6) Â« WGI Â»

AR6

SF6, a greenhouse gas (GHG), is mainly used in heavy industry to insulate high-voltage equipment and to assist in the manufacturing of cable-cooling systems and semiconductors.

Sulphur_hexafluoride__SF6_.html

Sulphur hexafluoride (SF6)

WGI

Sunspots_S.html

Sunspots Â« WGI Â»

AR6

Dark areas on the Sun where strong magnetic fields reduce the convection, causing a temperature reduction of about 1500 K compared to the surrounding regions. The number of sunspots is higher during periods of higher solar activity and varies in particular with the solar cycle.

Sunspots.html

Sunspots

Dark areas on the Sun where strong magnetic fields reduce the convection, causing a temperature reduction of about 1500 K compared to the surrounding regions. The number of sunspots is higher during periods of higher solar activity and varies in particular with the solar cycle.

WGI

Supply_side_measures_S.html

Supply-side measures Â« WGIII Â»

AR6

Policies and programmes for influencing how a certain demand for goods and/or services is met. In the energy sector, supply-side mitigation measures aim at reducing the amount of greenhouse gas emissions emitted per unit of energy service produced.

Parent-term
  • Demand- and supply-side measures

Supply_side_measures.html

Supply-side measures

Policies and programmes for influencing how a certain demand for goods and/or services is met. In the energy sector, supply-side mitigation measures aim at reducing the amount of greenhouse gas emissions emitted per unit of energy service produced.

Parent-term
  • Demand- and supply-side measures
WGIII

Surface energy budget Â« WGI Â»

AR6

comprises the exchanges of heat at the surface of the Earth associated with both radiative and non-radiative processes. Typical units: W m-2.

  • Earthâs energy budget

Surprises_S.html

Surprises Â« WGI Â»

AR6

A class of risk that can be defined as low-likelihood but well-understood events and events that cannot be predicted with current understanding (see Section 1.4.4.3 in AR6 WGI Chapter 1).

Sustainability_S.html

Sustainability Â« WGIII,WGII Â»

AR6

A dynamic process that guarantees the persistence of natural and human systems in an equitable manner.

Sustainability

A dynamic process that guarantees the persistence of natural and human systems in an equitable manner.

WGIII,WGII

Sustainable_Development_Goals__SDGs__S.html

Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) Â« WGIII,WGII Â»

AR6

The 17 global goals for development for all countries established by the United Nations through a participatory process and elaborated in the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, including ending poverty and hunger; ensuring health and well-being, education, gender equality, clean water and energy, and decent work; building and ensuring resilient and sustainable infrastructure, cities and consumption; reducing inequalities; protecting land and water ecosystems; promoting peace, justice and partnerships; and taking urgent action on climate change.

Sustainable_Development_Goals__SDGs_.html

Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)

The 17 global goals for development for all countries established by the United Nations through a participatory process and elaborated in the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, including ending poverty and hunger; ensuring health and well-being, education, gender equality, clean water and energy, and decent work; building and ensuring resilient and sustainable infrastructure, cities and consumption; reducing inequalities; protecting land and water ecosystems; promoting peace, justice and partnerships; and taking urgent action on climate change.

WGIII,WGII

Sustainable_development__SD__S.html

Sustainable development (SD) Â« WGIII,WGII Â»

AR6

Development that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs (WCED, 1987) and balances social, economic and environmental concerns.

Sustainable_development__SD_.html

Sustainable development

Development that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs (WCED, 1987) and balances social, economic and environmental concerns.

WGIII,WGII
SD

Sustainable_development_pathways__SDPs__S.html

Sustainable development pathways (SDPs) Â« WGII Â»

AR6

Trajectories aimed at attaining the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) in the short term and the goals of sustainable development in the long term. In the context of climate change, such pathways denote trajectories that address social, environmental and economic dimensions of sustainable development, adaptation and mitigation, and transformation, in a generic sense or from a particular methodological perspective such as integrated assessment models and scenario simulations.

Parent-term
  • Pathways

Sustainable_development_pathways__SDPs_.html

Sustainable development pathways (SDPs)

Trajectories aimed at attaining the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) in the short term and the goals of sustainable development in the long term. In the context of climate change, such pathways denote trajectories that address social, environmental and economic dimensions of sustainable development, adaptation and mitigation, and transformation, in a generic sense or from a particular methodological perspective such as integrated assessment models and scenario simulations.

Parent-term
  • Pathways
WGII

Sustainable_forest_management_S.html

Sustainable forest management Â« WGIII,WGII Â»

AR6

The stewardship and use of forests and forest lands in a way, and at a rate, that maintains their biodiversity, productivity, regeneration capacity, vitality and their potential to fulfil, now and in the future, relevant ecological, economic and social functions, at local, national, and global levels, and that does not cause damage to other ecosystems (Forest Europe, 1993).

Sustainable_forest_management.html

Sustainable forest management

The stewardship and use of forests and forest lands in a way, and at a rate, that maintains their biodiversity, productivity, regeneration capacity, vitality and their potential to fulfil, now and in the future, relevant ecological, economic and social functions, at local, national, and global levels, and that does not cause damage to other ecosystems (Forest Europe, 1993).

WGIII,WGII

Sustainable_intensification__of_agriculture__S.html

Sustainable intensification (of agriculture) Â« WGIII Â»

AR6

Increasing yields from the same area of land while decreasing negative environmental impacts of agricultural production and increasing the provision of environmental services (CGIAR, 2019).
[Note: This definition is based on the concept of meeting demand from a finite land area, but it is scale-dependent. Sustainable intensification at a given scale (e.g., global or national) may require a decrease in production intensity at smaller scales and in particular places (often associated with previous, unsustainable, intensification) to achieve sustainability (Garnett et al., 2013).]

Sustainable_intensification__of_agriculture_.html

Sustainable intensification (of agriculture)

Increasing yields from the same area of land while decreasing negative environmental impacts of agricultural production and increasing the provision of environmental services (CGIAR, 2019).
[Note: This definition is based on the concept of meeting demand from a finite land area, but it is scale-dependent. Sustainable intensification at a given scale (e.g., global or national) may require a decrease in production intensity at smaller scales and in particular places (often associated with previous, unsustainable, intensification) to achieve sustainability (Garnett et al., 2013).]

WGIII

Sustainable_land_management_S.html

Sustainable land management Â« WGIII,WGII Â»

AR6

The stewardship and use of land resources, including soils, water, animals and plants, to meet changing human needs, while simultaneously ensuring the long-term productive potential of these resources and the maintenance of their environmental functions.

Sustainable_land_management.html

Sustainable land management

The stewardship and use of land resources, including soils, water, animals and plants, to meet changing human needs, while simultaneously ensuring the long-term productive potential of these resources and the maintenance of their environmental functions.

Swash Â« WGI Â»

AR6

Vertical displacement up the shore-face induced by individual waves.

Swash.html

Swash

AR6

Organisms and habitats related to the sea ice, analogous to pelagic (water column) or benthic (seafloor).

Sympagic

WGII

Systems_of_Innovation__SI__S.html

Systems of Innovation (SI) Â« WGIII Â»

AR6

The set of public and private sector organisations (i.e., formally organised entities such as firms and universities; âactorsâ) and institutions, whose activities and interactions generate, modify and deploy new technologies. The SI approach has been used to understand and analyse innovation at the national, regional, and technological levels, and in transnational contexts (Lundvall, 1988, 1992).

References
- Lundvall, B., 1988: Innovation as an interactive process: from user-producer interaction to the national system of innovation. Technical Change and Economic Theory, G. Dosi, C. Freeman, R. Nelson, G. Silverberg, and L. Soete, Eds., Pinter Publishers.
- Lundvall, B., 1992: National Systems of Innovation: Toward a Theory of Innovation and Interactive Learning. B. Lundvall, Ed. Pinter Publishers, 342 pp.

Systems_of_Innovation__SI_.html

Systems of Innovation

The set of public and private sector organisations (i.e., formally organised entities such as firms and universities; âactorsâ) and institutions, whose activities and interactions generate, modify and deploy new technologies. The SI approach has been used to understand and analyse innovation at the national, regional, and technological levels, and in transnational contexts (Lundvall, 1988, 1992).

References
- Lundvall, B., 1988: Innovation as an interactive process: from user-producer interaction to the national system of innovation. Technical Change and Economic Theory, G. Dosi, C. Freeman, R. Nelson, G. Silverberg, and L. Soete, Eds., Pinter Publishers.
- Lundvall, B., 1992: National Systems of Innovation: Toward a Theory of Innovation and Interactive Learning. B. Lundvall, Ed. Pinter Publishers, 342 pp.

SI

Talik_T.html

Talik Â« WGI Â»

AR6

A layer or body of unfrozen ground in a permafrost area due to a local anomaly in thermal, hydrological, hydrogeological or hydrochemical conditions (IPA, 2005).

Talik.html

Talik

A layer or body of unfrozen ground in a permafrost area due to a local anomaly in thermal, hydrological, hydrogeological or hydrochemical conditions (IPA, 2005).

WGI

Technical_potential_T.html

Technical potential Â« WGIII,WGI Â»

AR6

The mitigation potential constrained by biogeophysical limits as well as availability of technologies and practices. Quantification of technical potentials takes into account primarily technical considerations, but social, economic and/or environmental considerations are occasionally also included, if these represent strong barriers for the deployment of an option.

Parent-term
  • Mitigation potential

Technical_potential.html

Technical potential

The mitigation potential constrained by biogeophysical limits as well as availability of technologies and practices. Quantification of technical potentials takes into account primarily technical considerations, but social, economic and/or environmental considerations are occasionally also included, if these represent strong barriers for the deployment of an option.

Parent-term
  • Mitigation potential
WGIII,WGI

Technology_deployment_T.html

Technology deployment Â« WGIII Â»

AR6

The act of bringing technology into effective application, involving a set of actors and activities to initiate, facilitate and/or support its implementation.

Technology_deployment.html

Technology deployment

The act of bringing technology into effective application, involving a set of actors and activities to initiate, facilitate and/or support its implementation.

AR6

The spread of a technology across different groups users/markets over time.

Technology_diffusion.html

Technology diffusion

The spread of a technology across different groups users/markets over time.

WGIII

Technology_transfer_T.html

Technology transfer Â« WGIII Â»

AR6

The exchange of knowledge, hardware and associated software, money and goods among stakeholders, which leads to the spread of technology for adaptation or mitigation. The term encompasses both diffusion of technologies and technological cooperation across and within countries.

Technology_transfer.html

Technology transfer

The exchange of knowledge, hardware and associated software, money and goods among stakeholders, which leads to the spread of technology for adaptation or mitigation. The term encompasses both diffusion of technologies and technological cooperation across and within countries.

WGIII

Teleconnection_T.html

Teleconnection Â« WGI,WGIII,WGII Â»

AR6

Association between climate variables at widely separated, geographically fixed locations related to each other through physical processes and oceanic and/or atmospheric dynamical pathways. Teleconnections can be caused by several climate phenomena, such as Rossby wave-trains, mid-latitude jet and storm track displacements, fluctuations of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC), fluctuations of the Walker circulation, etc. They can be initiated by modes of climate variability, thus providing the development of remote climate anomalies at various temporal lags.

Teleconnection.html

Teleconnection

Association between climate variables at widely separated, geographically fixed locations related to each other through physical processes and oceanic and/or atmospheric dynamical pathways. Teleconnections can be caused by several climate phenomena, such as Rossby wave-trains, mid-latitude jet and storm track displacements, fluctuations of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC), fluctuations of the Walker circulation, etc. They can be initiated by modes of climate variability, thus providing the development of remote climate anomalies at various temporal lags.

WGI,WGIII,WGII

Teleconnection_pattern_T.html

Teleconnection pattern Â« WGI Â»

AR6

Spatial structure of climate anomalies that are linked to each other through teleconnection processes or that are the large-scale fingerprint of modes of climate variability. Teleconnection patterns can be visualized using correlation and/or regression maps of climate variables with some climate indices (i.e., those derived from the temporal variation of the main modes of climate variability). They can also be obtained from principal component analysis, singular value decomposition/maximum covariance analysis, clustering based on spatial recurrence criteria, etc. See also Section Atlas.3.1 of the AR6 WGI report and Teleconnection.

Teleconnection_pattern.html

Teleconnection pattern

Spatial structure of climate anomalies that are linked to each other through teleconnection processes or that are the large-scale fingerprint of modes of climate variability. Teleconnection patterns can be visualized using correlation and/or regression maps of climate variables with some climate indices (i.e., those derived from the temporal variation of the main modes of climate variability). They can also be obtained from principal component analysis, singular value decomposition/maximum covariance analysis, clustering based on spatial recurrence criteria, etc. See also Section Atlas.3.1 of the AR6 WGI report and Teleconnection.

WGI

Temperature_overshoot_T.html

Temperature overshoot Â« WGI,WGIII,WGII Â»

AR6

Exceedance of a specified global warming level, followed by a decline to or below that level during a specified period of time (e.g., before 2100). Sometimes the magnitude and likelihood of the overshoot is also characterised. The overshoot duration can vary from one pathway to the next, but in most overshoot pathways in the literature and as referred to as overshoot pathways in the AR6, the overshoot occurs over a period of at least one decade and up to several decades.

Temperature_overshoot.html

Temperature overshoot

Exceedance of a specified global warming level, followed by a decline to or below that level during a specified period of time (e.g., before 2100). Sometimes the magnitude and likelihood of the overshoot is also characterised. The overshoot duration can vary from one pathway to the next, but in most overshoot pathways in the literature and as referred to as overshoot pathways in the AR6, the overshoot occurs over a period of at least one decade and up to several decades.

WGI,WGIII,WGII

Terrestrial_radiation_T.html

Terrestrial radiation Â« WGI Â»

AR6

Radiation emitted by the Earthâs surface, the atmosphere and clouds. It is also known as thermal infrared or longwave radiation and is to be distinguished from the near-infrared radiation that is part of the solar spectrum. Infrared radiation, in general, has a distinctive range of wavelengths (spectrum) longer than the wavelength of the red light in the visible part of the spectrum. The spectrum of terrestrial radiation is almost entirely distinct from that of shortwave or solar radiation because of the difference in temperature between the Sun and the Earthâatmosphere system.

Terrestrial_radiation.html

Terrestrial radiation

Radiation emitted by the Earthâs surface, the atmosphere and clouds. It is also known as thermal infrared or longwave radiation and is to be distinguished from the near-infrared radiation that is part of the solar spectrum. Infrared radiation, in general, has a distinctive range of wavelengths (spectrum) longer than the wavelength of the red light in the visible part of the spectrum. The spectrum of terrestrial radiation is almost entirely distinct from that of shortwave or solar radiation because of the difference in temperature between the Sun and the Earthâatmosphere system.

WGI

Thermocline_T.html

Thermocline Â« WGI Â»

AR6

The layer of maximum vertical temperature gradient in the ocean, lying between the surface ocean and the abyssal ocean. In subtropical regions, its source waters are typically surface waters at higher latitudes that have subducted (see Subduction) and moved equatorward. At high latitudes, it is sometimes absent, replaced by a halocline, which is a layer of maximum vertical salinity gradient.

Thermocline.html

Thermocline

The layer of maximum vertical temperature gradient in the ocean, lying between the surface ocean and the abyssal ocean. In subtropical regions, its source waters are typically surface waters at higher latitudes that have subducted (see Subduction) and moved equatorward. At high latitudes, it is sometimes absent, replaced by a halocline, which is a layer of maximum vertical salinity gradient.

WGI

Thermokarst_T.html

Thermokarst Â« WGI Â»

AR6

Process by which characteristic landforms result from thawing of ice-rich permafrost or melting of massive ice (IPA, 2005).

References
- Multi-language glossary of permafrost and related ground ice terms, version 2.0 (revised 2005), R.O van Everdingen editor. University of Calgary, Canada. https://globalcryospherewatch.org/reference/glossary_docs/Glossary_of_Permafrost_and_Ground-Ice_IPA_2005.pdf

Thermokarst.html

Thermokarst

WGI

Thermosteric_sea_level_change_T.html

Thermosteric sea level change Â« WGI Â»

AR6

Thermosteric sea level change (where thermosteric sea level rise may also be referred to as thermal expansion) occurs as a result of changes in ocean temperature: increasing temperature reduces ocean density and increases the volume per unit of mass.

Parent-term
  • Sea level change (sea level rise/sea level fall)

Thermosteric_sea_level_change.html

Thermosteric sea level change

Thermosteric sea level change (where thermosteric sea level rise may also be referred to as thermal expansion) occurs as a result of changes in ocean temperature: increasing temperature reduces ocean density and increases the volume per unit of mass.

Parent-term
  • Sea level change (sea level rise/sea level fall)
WGI

Tide_gauge_T.html

Tide gauge Â« WGI Â»

AR6

A device at a coastal or deep-sea location that continuously measures the level of the sea with respect to the adjacent land. Time averaging of the sea level so recorded gives the observed secular changes of the relative sea level.

Tide_gauge.html

Tide gauge

A device at a coastal or deep-sea location that continuously measures the level of the sea with respect to the adjacent land. Time averaging of the sea level so recorded gives the observed secular changes of the relative sea level.

WGI

Tier_T.html

Tier Â« WGII Â»

AR6

In the context of the IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories, a tier represents a level of methodological complexity. Usually three tiers are provided. Tier 1 is the basic method, Tier 2 intermediate and Tier 3 most demanding in terms of complexity and data requirements. Tiers 2 and 3 are sometimes referred to as higher-tier methods and are generally considered to be more accurate (IPCC, 2019).

Tier.html

Tier

In the context of the IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories, a tier represents a level of methodological complexity. Usually three tiers are provided. Tier 1 is the basic method, Tier 2 intermediate and Tier 3 most demanding in terms of complexity and data requirements. Tiers 2 and 3 are sometimes referred to as higher-tier methods and are generally considered to be more accurate (IPCC, 2019).

WGII

Time_of_emergence__ToE__T.html

Time of emergence (ToE) Â« WGI Â»

AR6

Time when a specific anthropogenic signal related to climate change is statistically detected to emerge from the background noise of natural climate variability in a reference period, for a specific region (Hawkins and Sutton, 2012).

Time_of_emergence__ToE_.html

Time of emergence (ToE)

Time when a specific anthropogenic signal related to climate change is statistically detected to emerge from the background noise of natural climate variability in a reference period, for a specific region (Hawkins and Sutton, 2012).

Tipping element

Tipping point

WGI,WGIII,WGII

Top_of_atmosphere_energy_budget_T.html

Top-of-atmosphere energy budget Â« WGI Â»

AR6

Comprises the energy fluxes associated with incoming solar radiation, reflected solar radiation and emitted thermal radiation. Typical units: W m-2.

Parent-term
  • Earthâs energy budget

Top_of_atmosphere_energy_budget.html

Top-of-atmosphere energy budget

Comprises the energy fluxes associated with incoming solar radiation, reflected solar radiation and emitted thermal radiation. Typical units: W m-2.

  • Earthâs energy budget
WGI

Total_alkalinity_T.html

Total alkalinity Â« WGI Â»

AR6

Total Alkalinity (AT) is a measurable parameter of the seawater acidâbase system which, when expressed in micromoles per kilogram of seawater, is a conservative variable both on mixing and for changes in temperature and/or pressure. Changes in total alkalinity in the oceans can result from a variety of biogeochemical processes that affect the acidâbase composition of the seawater itself. However, its value is not affected by the exchange of carbon dioxide gas between seawater and the atmosphere. Measurements of total alkalinity can thus be used to help study these biogeochemical processes and can also be used to help calculate the state of the seawater acidâbase system. Total alkalinity is most commonly measured using an acidimetric titration technique that determines how much acid is required to titrate a seawater sample to a specified equivalence point.

Total_alkalinity.html

Total alkalinity

Total Alkalinity (AT) is a measurable parameter of the seawater acidâbase system which, when expressed in micromoles per kilogram of seawater, is a conservative variable both on mixing and for changes in temperature and/or pressure. Changes in total alkalinity in the oceans can result from a variety of biogeochemical processes that affect the acidâbase composition of the seawater itself. However, its value is not affected by the exchange of carbon dioxide gas between seawater and the atmosphere. Measurements of total alkalinity can thus be used to help study these biogeochemical processes and can also be used to help calculate the state of the seawater acidâbase system. Total alkalinity is most commonly measured using an acidimetric titration technique that determines how much acid is required to titrate a seawater sample to a specified equivalence point.

WGI

Total_carbon_budget_T.html

Total carbon budget Â« WGIII,WGI Â»

AR6

Refers to two concepts in the literature: (i) an assessment of carbon cycle sources and sinks on a global
level, through the synthesis of evidence for fossil fuel and cement emissions, emissions and removals associated with land use and land-use change, ocean and natural land sources and sinks of carbon dioxide (CO2), and the resulting change in atmospheric CO2 concentration.This is referred to as the total carbon budget when expressed starting from the pre-industrial period, and as the remaining carbon budget when expressed from a recent specified date.

Total_carbon_budget.html

Total carbon budget

Refers to two concepts in the literature: (i) an assessment of carbon cycle sources and sinks on a global
level, through the synthesis of evidence for fossil fuel and cement emissions, emissions and removals associated with land use and land-use change, ocean and natural land sources and sinks of carbon dioxide (CO2), and the resulting change in atmospheric CO2 concentration.This is referred to as the total carbon budget when expressed starting from the pre-industrial period, and as the remaining carbon budget when expressed from a recent specified date.

WGIII,WGI

Total_solar_irradiance__TSI__T.html

Total solar irradiance (TSI) Â« WGI Â»

AR6

The total amount of solar radiation in watts per square metre received outside the Earthâs atmosphere on a surface normal to the incident radiation, and at the Earthâs mean distance from the Sun. Reliable measurements of solar radiation can only be made from space, and the precise record extends back only to 1978. Variations of a few tenths of a percent are common, usually associated with the passage of sunspots across the solar disk. The solar cycle variation of TSI is of the order of 0.1% (AMS, 2021).

References
- AMS, 2021: Glossary of Meteorology. American Meteorological Society (AMS), Boston, MA, USA. Retrieved from: http://glossary.ametsoc.org.

Total_solar_irradiance__TSI_.html

Total solar irradiance

The total amount of solar radiation in watts per square metre received outside the Earthâs atmosphere on a surface normal to the incident radiation, and at the Earthâs mean distance from the Sun. Reliable measurements of solar radiation can only be made from space, and the precise record extends back only to 1978. Variations of a few tenths of a percent are common, usually associated with the passage of sunspots across the solar disk. The solar cycle variation of TSI is of the order of 0.1% (AMS, 2021).

References
- AMS, 2021: Glossary of Meteorology. American Meteorological Society (AMS), Boston, MA, USA. Retrieved from: http://glossary.ametsoc.org.
WGI
TSI

Total_water_level_T.html

Total water level Â« WGI Â»

AR6

Extreme total water level (ETWL) is the Extreme still water level (ESWL) plus wave setup. When considering coastal impacts, swash is also important, and Extreme coastal water level (ECWL) is used.

Total_water_level.html

Total water level

Extreme total water level (ETWL) is the Extreme still water level (ESWL) plus wave setup. When considering coastal impacts, swash is also important, and Extreme coastal water level (ECWL) is used.

WGI

Trace_gas_T.html

Trace gas Â« WGI Â»

AR6

A minor constituent of the atmosphere, next to nitrogen and oxygen that together make up 99 % of all volume. The most important trace gases contributing to the greenhouse effect are carbon dioxide (CO2), ozone (O3), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), sulphur hexafluoride (SF6) and water vapour (H2O).

Trace_gas.html

Trace gas

A minor constituent of the atmosphere, next to nitrogen and oxygen that together make up 99 % of all volume. The most important trace gases contributing to the greenhouse effect are carbon dioxide (CO2), ozone (O3), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), sulphur hexafluoride (SF6) and water vapour (H2O).

WGI

Trade_off_T.html

Trade-off Â« WGIII,WGII Â»

AR6

A competition between different objectives within a decision situation, where pursuing one objective will diminish achievement of other objective(s). A trade-off exists when a policy or measure aimed at one objective (e.g., reducing greenhouse gas emissions) reduces outcomes for other objective(s) (e.g., biodiversity conservation, energy security) due to adverse side effects, thereby potentially reducing the net benefit to society or the environment.

Trade_off.html

Trade-off

A competition between different objectives within a decision situation, where pursuing one objective will diminish achievement of other objective(s). A trade-off exists when a policy or measure aimed at one objective (e.g., reducing greenhouse gas emissions) reduces outcomes for other objective(s) (e.g., biodiversity conservation, energy security) due to adverse side effects, thereby potentially reducing the net benefit to society or the environment.

WGIII,WGII

Traditional_biomass_T.html

Traditional biomass Â« WGIII Â»

AR6

The combustion of wood, charcoal, agricultural residues and/or animal dung for cooking or heating in open fires or in inefficient stoves as is common in low-income countries.

Parent-term
  • Biomass

Traditional_biomass.html

Traditional biomass

The combustion of wood, charcoal, agricultural residues and/or animal dung for cooking or heating in open fires or in inefficient stoves as is common in low-income countries.

Parent-term
  • Biomass
WGIII

Transformation Â« WGIII,WGII Â»

AR6

A change in the fundamental attributes of natural and human systems.

Sub-terms
  • Deliberate transformations
  • Societal (social) transformations

Transformation

  • Societal (social) transformations
WGIII,WGII

Transformation_pathways_T.html

Transformation pathways Â« WGIII Â»

AR6

Trajectories describing consistent sets of possible futures of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, atmospheric concentrations, or global mean surface temperatures implied from mitigation and adaptation actions associated with a set of broad and irreversible economic, technological, societal, and behavioural changes. This can encompass changes in the way energy and infrastructure are used and produced, natural resources are managed and institutions are set up and in the pace and direction of technological change.

Parent-term
  • Pathways

Transformation_pathways.html

Transformation pathways

Trajectories describing consistent sets of possible futures of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, atmospheric concentrations, or global mean surface temperatures implied from mitigation and adaptation actions associated with a set of broad and irreversible economic, technological, societal, and behavioural changes. This can encompass changes in the way energy and infrastructure are used and produced, natural resources are managed and institutions are set up and in the pace and direction of technological change.

Parent-term
  • Pathways
WGIII

Transformational_adaptation_T.html

Transformational adaptation Â« WGIII,WGII Â»

AR6

Adaptation that changes the fundamental attributes of a social-ecological system in anticipation of climate change and its impacts.

Parent-term
  • Adaptation

Transformational_adaptation.html

Transformational adaptation

Adaptation that changes the fundamental attributes of a social-ecological system in anticipation of climate change and its impacts.

Parent-term
  • Adaptation
WGIII,WGII

Transformative_change_T.html

Transformative change Â« WGII Â»

AR6

A system-wide change that requires more than technological change through consideration of social and economic factors that, with technology, can bring about rapid change at scale.

Transformative_change.html

Transformative change

A system-wide change that requires more than technological change through consideration of social and economic factors that, with technology, can bring about rapid change at scale.

WGII

Transient_climate_response__TCR__T.html

Transient climate response (TCR) Â« WGI,WGIII Â»

AR6

The surface temperature response for the hypothetical scenario in which atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) increases at 1% yr-1 from pre-industrial to the time of a doubling of atmospheric CO2 concentration (year 70).

Parent-term
  • Climate sensitivity

Transient_climate_response__TCR_.html

Transient climate response

The surface temperature response for the hypothetical scenario in which atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) increases at 1% yr-1 from pre-industrial to the time of a doubling of atmospheric CO2 concentration (year 70).

Parent-term
  • Climate sensitivity
WGI,WGIII
TCR

Transient_climate_response_to_cumulative_CO2_emissions__TCRE__T.html

Transient climate response to cumulative CO2 emissions (TCRE) Â« WGIII,WGI Â»

AR6

The transient surface temperature change per unit cumulative carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions, usually 1000 GtC. TCRE combines both information on the airborne fraction of cumulative CO2 emissions (the fraction of the total CO2 emitted that remains in the atmosphere, which is determined by carbon cycle processes) and on the transient climate response (TCR).

Parent-term
  • Climate sensitivity

Transient_climate_response_to_cumulative_CO2_emissions__TCRE_.html

Transient climate response to cumulative CO2 emissions

The transient surface temperature change per unit cumulative carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions, usually 1000 GtC. TCRE combines both information on the airborne fraction of cumulative CO2 emissions (the fraction of the total CO2 emitted that remains in the atmosphere, which is determined by carbon cycle processes) and on the transient climate response (TCR).

Parent-term
  • Climate sensitivity
WGIII,WGI
TCRE

Transition_T.html

Transition Â« WGIII,WGII Â»

AR6

The process of changing from one state or condition to another in a given period of time. Transition can occur in individuals, firms, cities, regions and nations, and can be based on incremental or transformative change.

Sub-terms
  • Just transitions

Transition.html

Transition

The process of changing from one state or condition to another in a given period of time. Transition can occur in individuals, firms, cities, regions and nations, and can be based on incremental or transformative change.

Sub-terms
  • Just transitions
WGIII,WGII

Tree_line_T.html

Tree line Â« WGII Â»

AR6

The upper limit of tree growth in mountains or at high latitudes. It is more elevated or more poleward than the forest line.

Tree_line.html

Tree line

The upper limit of tree growth in mountains or at high latitudes. It is more elevated or more poleward than the forest line.

WGII

Tree_rings_T.html

Tree rings Â« WGI Â»

AR6

Concentric rings of secondary wood evident in a cross section of the stem of a woody plant. The difference between the dense, small-celled late wood of one season and the wide-celled early wood of the following spring enables the age of a tree to be estimated, and the ring widths or density can be related to climate parameters such as temperature and precipitation.

Tree_rings.html

Tree rings

Concentric rings of secondary wood evident in a cross section of the stem of a woody plant. The difference between the dense, small-celled late wood of one season and the wide-celled early wood of the following spring enables the age of a tree to be estimated, and the ring widths or density can be related to climate parameters such as temperature and precipitation.

WGI

Trend_estimates_uncertainty_T.html

Trend estimates uncertainty Â« WGI Â»

AR6

Uncertainty arising from data fitting to a time-series with potential non-linear and autorogressive character.

Trend_estimates_uncertainty.html

Trend estimates uncertainty

Uncertainty arising from data fitting to a time-series with potential non-linear and autorogressive character.

WGI

Tropical_Atlantic_Variability__TAV__T.html

Tropical Atlantic Variability (TAV) Â« WGI Â»

AR6

A generic term to describe the climate variability of the tropical Atlantic which is dominated at interannual to decadal time scales by two main climate modes: the Atlantic Zonal Mode (AZM) and the Atlantic Meridional Mode (AMM). The Atlantic Zonal Mode, also commonly referred to as the Atlantic NiÃ±o or Atlantic equatorial mode, is associated with sea surface temperature anomalies near the equator, peaking in the eastern basin, while the Atlantic meridional mode is characterized by an inter-hemispheric gradient of sea surface temperature and wind anomalies. Both modes are associated with significant teleconnections over Africa and South America.

Sub-terms
  • Atlantic Meridional Mode (AMM)
  • Atlantic Zonal Mode (AZM)

Tropical_Atlantic_Variability__TAV_.html

Tropical Atlantic Variability

A generic term to describe the climate variability of the tropical Atlantic which is dominated at interannual to decadal time scales by two main climate modes: the Atlantic Zonal Mode (AZM) and the Atlantic Meridional Mode (AMM). The Atlantic Zonal Mode, also commonly referred to as the Atlantic NiÃ±o or Atlantic equatorial mode, is associated with sea surface temperature anomalies near the equator, peaking in the eastern basin, while the Atlantic meridional mode is characterized by an inter-hemispheric gradient of sea surface temperature and wind anomalies. Both modes are associated with significant teleconnections over Africa and South America.

Sub-terms
  • Atlantic Meridional Mode (AMM)
  • Atlantic Zonal Mode (AZM)
WGI
TAV

Tropical_cyclone_T.html

Tropical cyclone Â« WGII,WGI Â»

AR6

The general term for a strong, cyclonic-scale disturbance that originates over tropical oceans. Distinguished from weaker systems (often named tropical disturbances or depressions) by exceeding a threshold wind speed. A tropical storm is a tropical cyclone with one-minute average surface winds between 18 and 32 m sâ1. Beyond 32 m sâ1, a tropical cyclone is called a hurricane, typhoon or cyclone, depending on geographic location.

Tropical_cyclone.html

Tropical cyclone

The general term for a strong, cyclonic-scale disturbance that originates over tropical oceans. Distinguished from weaker systems (often named tropical disturbances or depressions) by exceeding a threshold wind speed. A tropical storm is a tropical cyclone with one-minute average surface winds between 18 and 32 m sâ1. Beyond 32 m sâ1, a tropical cyclone is called a hurricane, typhoon or cyclone, depending on geographic location.

WGII,WGI

Tropopause_T.html

Tropopause Â« WGI Â»

AR6

The boundary between the troposphere and the stratosphere. It ranges from 8â9 km at high latitudes to 15â16 km in the tropics.

Tropopause.html

Tropopause

The boundary between the troposphere and the stratosphere. It ranges from 8â9 km at high latitudes to 15â16 km in the tropics.

WGI

Troposphere_T.html

Troposphere Â« WGI Â»

AR6

The lowest part of the atmosphere, below the tropopause, where clouds and weather phenomena occur. In the troposphere, temperatures generally decrease with height.

Troposphere.html

Troposphere

The lowest part of the atmosphere, below the tropopause, where clouds and weather phenomena occur. In the troposphere, temperatures generally decrease with height.

AR6

A wave, or train of waves, produced by a disturbance such as a submarine earthquake displacing the sea floor, a landslide, a volcanic eruption or an asteroid impact.

Tsunami

WGI,WGII

Turnover_time__T__T.html

Turnover time (T) Â« WGI Â»

AR6

(also called global atmospheric lifetime) is the ratio of the mass M of a reservoir (e.g., a gaseous compound in the atmosphere) and the total rate of removal S from the reservoir: T = M/S. For each removal process, separate turnover times can be defined. In soil carbon biology, this is referred to as mean residence time.

Parent-term
  • Lifetime

Turnover_time__T_.html

Turnover time

(also called global atmospheric lifetime) is the ratio of the mass M of a reservoir (e.g., a gaseous compound in the atmosphere) and the total rate of removal S from the reservoir: T = M/S. For each removal process, separate turnover times can be defined. In soil carbon biology, this is referred to as mean residence time.

Parent-term
  • Lifetime
WGI
T

Typological_regions_T.html

Typological regions Â« WGI Â»

AR6

Regions of the Earth that share one or more specific features (known as âtypologiesâ), such as geographic location (e.g., coastal), physical processes (e.g., monsoons), and biological (e.g., coral reefs, tropical forests), geological (e.g., mountains) or anthropogenic (e.g., megacities) formation, and for which it is useful to consider the common climate features. Typological regions are smaller than climatic zones (e.g., a mountain region) and can be discontinuous (e.g., a group of megacities affected by the urban heat island effect, or monsoon regions).

Typological_regions.html

Typological regions

Regions of the Earth that share one or more specific features (known as âtypologiesâ), such as geographic location (e.g., coastal), physical processes (e.g., monsoons), and biological (e.g., coral reefs, tropical forests), geological (e.g., mountains) or anthropogenic (e.g., megacities) formation, and for which it is useful to consider the common climate features. Typological regions are smaller than climatic zones (e.g., a mountain region) and can be discontinuous (e.g., a group of megacities affected by the urban heat island effect, or monsoon regions).

WGI

Uncertainty_U.html

Uncertainty Â« WGI,WGIII,WGII Â»

AR6

A state of incomplete knowledge that can result from a lack of information or from disagreement about what is known or even knowable. It may have many types of sources, from imprecision in the data to ambiguously defined concepts or terminology, incomplete understanding of critical processes or uncertain projections of human behaviour. Uncertainty can therefore be represented by quantitative measures (e.g., a probability density function) or by qualitative statements (e.g., reflecting the judgement of a team of experts) (Moss and Schneider, 2000; IPCC, 2004; Mastrandrea et al., 2010).

Sub-terms
  • Deep uncertainty
  • Interpolation uncertainty
  • Sampling uncertainty

Uncertainty.html

Uncertainty

A state of incomplete knowledge that can result from a lack of information or from disagreement about what is known or even knowable. It may have many types of sources, from imprecision in the data to ambiguously defined concepts or terminology, incomplete understanding of critical processes or uncertain projections of human behaviour. Uncertainty can therefore be represented by quantitative measures (e.g., a probability density function) or by qualitative statements (e.g., reflecting the judgement of a team of experts) (Moss and Schneider, 2000; IPCC, 2004; Mastrandrea et al., 2010).

Sub-terms
  • Deep uncertainty
  • Interpolation uncertainty
  • Sampling uncertainty
WGI,WGIII,WGII

United_Nations_Convention_to_Combat_Desertification__UNCCD__U.html

United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification (UNCCD) Â« WGIII Â»

AR6

A legally binding international agreement linking environment and development to sustainable land management, established in 1994. The Conventionâs objective is âto combat desertification and mitigate the effects of drought in countries experiencing drought and/or desertificationâ. The Convention specifically addresses the arid, semi-arid and dry sub-humid areas, known as the drylands, and has a particular focus on Africa. As of September 2020, the UNCCD had 197 Parties.

United_Nations_Convention_to_Combat_Desertification__UNCCD_.html

United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification

A legally binding international agreement linking environment and development to sustainable land management, established in 1994. The Conventionâs objective is âto combat desertification and mitigate the effects of drought in countries experiencing drought and/or desertificationâ. The Convention specifically addresses the arid, semi-arid and dry sub-humid areas, known as the drylands, and has a particular focus on Africa. As of September 2020, the UNCCD had 197 Parties.

WGIII
UNCCD

United_Nations_Framework_Convention_on_Climate_Change__UNFCCC__U.html

United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) Â« WGIII,WGII,WGI Â»

AR6

The UNFCCC was adopted in May 1992 and opened for signature at the 1992 Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro. It entered into force in March 1994 and, as of September 2020, had 197 Parties (196 States and the European Union). The Conventionâs ultimate objective is the âstabilization of greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere at a level that would prevent dangerous anthropogenic interference with the climate systemâ (UNFCCC, 1992). The provisions of the Convention are pursued and implemented by two further treaties: the Kyoto Protocol and the Paris Agreement.

United_Nations_Framework_Convention_on_Climate_Change__UNFCCC_.html

United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

The UNFCCC was adopted in May 1992 and opened for signature at the 1992 Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro. It entered into force in March 1994 and, as of September 2020, had 197 Parties (196 States and the European Union). The Conventionâs ultimate objective is the âstabilization of greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere at a level that would prevent dangerous anthropogenic interference with the climate systemâ (UNFCCC, 1992). The provisions of the Convention are pursued and implemented by two further treaties: the Kyoto Protocol and the Paris Agreement.

WGIII,WGII,WGI
UNFCCC

Uptake_U.html

Uptake Â« WGIII,WGII,WGI Â»

AR6

The transfer of substances (such as carbon) or energy (e.g., heat) from one compartment of a system to another; for example, in the Earth system from the atmosphere to the ocean or to the land.

Uptake.html

Uptake

The transfer of substances (such as carbon) or energy (e.g., heat) from one compartment of a system to another; for example, in the Earth system from the atmosphere to the ocean or to the land.
